Consider the reaction,
CH3CH2CH2Br + NaCN $$ \to $$ CH3CH2CH2CN + NaBr

This reaction will be the fastest in
_children.explanation:
The reaction,
CH3CH2CH2Br + NaCN $$ \to $$ CH3CH2CH2CN + NaBr

follows SN2 mechanism which is favoured by polar aprotic solvent i.e., N, N'–dimethylformamide (DMF).

_children.body: In an S<sub>N</sub>1 reaction on chiral centers, there is

options.value: inversion more than retention leading to partial racemisation

_children.explanation:
In case of optically active alkyl halides, SN1 reaction is accompanied by racemisation. The carbocation formed in the slow step being sp2 hybridised is planar and attack of nucleophile may take place from either side resulting in a mixture of products, one having the same configuration and other having inverted configuration.

The isomer corresponding to inversion is present in slight excess because SN1 also depends upon the degree of shielding of the front side of the reacting carbon.

_children.body: Which one is most reactive towards S<sub>N</sub>1 reaction?
_children.explanation:
S<sub>N</sub>1 reactions involve the formation of
carbocations, hence higher the stability of
intermediate carbocation, more will be reactivity
of the parent alkyl halide. The tertiary carbocation
formed from (c) is stabilized by two phenyl groups
and one methyl group, hence most stable.

_children.body: Which of the following reactions is an example of nucleophilic substitution reaction?
_children.explanation:
In nucleophilic substitution, a nucleophile
provides an electron pair to the substrate and
the leaving group departs with an electron pair.

_children.body: Which of the following undergoes nucleophilic substitution exclusively by S<sub>N</sub>1 mechanism?
_children.explanation:
SN1 reaction is favoured by heavy groups on the carbon atom attached to halogen i.e

Benzyl > allyl > tertiary > primary > secondary > primary > alkyl halides

_children.body: Reactivity order of halides for dehydrologenation is

options.value: $$R - F > R - Cl > R - Br > R - {\rm I}$$
$$R - {\rm I} > R - Br > R - Cl > R - F$$
$$R - {\rm I} > R - Cl > R - Br > R - F$$
$$R - F > R - {\rm I} > R - Br > R - Cl$$

_children.explanation:
atomic radii order :
I > Br > Cl > F

F, Cl, Br, I belongs to the same group orderly. Atomic radii go on increasing as the nuclear charge increases from top to bottom in a group. The decreasing order of bond length C – I > C – Br > C – Cl > C – F. The order of bond dissociation energy
R – F > R – Cl > R – Br > R – I. During dehydrohalogenation C – I bond breaks more easily than C – F bond.So reactivity order of halides

$$R - {\rm I} > R - Br > R - Cl > R - F$$
